content.text:
June 24, 2022
We have explored Australia for 2 weeks now. We left early in the morning and took a 140 km drive from Melbourne. After 1 hour and 45 minutes we arrived at the majestic Phillip Island, home to a hundred different species of animals and of around 7000 people. Although it is a small island it has scientific, historic and archaeological importance
content.name: B33f

content.text: Phillip Island was the favorite spot for fishing, hunting and foraging for the Bunurong people. The firsts Australian would cross over in the Summer months when wildlife was the most abundant. Phillip Island Nature Parks work hard to preserve these areas because of the cultural importance.
content.name: iJ6B

content.text: As we walked through the island, I noticed the absence of housing. This was because that area is part of the National Park. Penguins who have not gone fishing, hide in some man made burrows. We were able to spot a few Little Penguins sleeping in the burrows.  As we kept walking we arrived at the “Blowhole” where huge waves crash into the volcanic rock.
content.name: LlLF

content.text: As the sun began to set,  we made our way to the Penguin Parade. The Little Penguins only come out after the sun has gone down to stay away from predators in the air above them. We were not allowed to take any photographs as camera flashes could hurt the penguins sensitive eyes and scare them away. This was such an amazing day.
content.name: JfNX
